Jokowi: Indonesia Tolak Limbah Sampah dari Luar Negeri
04 Nov 2019, 16:51 by Bisnis.com, Rr. Ariyani Yakti Widyastuti
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - Presiden Joko Widodo atau Jokowi menegaskan bahwa Indonesia menolak menjadi tempat pembuangan sampah dari luar negeri. “Tentunya kita semua tidak ingin kawasan Asia Tenggara, menjadi tempat pembuangan limbah bahan berbahaya dan beracun,” ucap Presiden Joko Widodo, dikutip dari keterangan resminya, ketika menghadiri KTT ke-14 Asia Timur di Bangkok, Senin, 4 November 2019.
Beberapa waktu terakhir ini, sejumlah negara ASEAN menerima limbah bahan berbahaya dan beracun dari beberapa negara termasuk di kawasan Asia Timur. Pembuangan limbah bahan berbahaya itu, menurut Jokowi, melanggar aturan internasional mengenai limbah plastik dan limbah beracun berbahaya.
Terkait hal itu, Jokowi mengusulkan kerja sama penanganan limbah B3 dan sampah plastik pada KTT ke-14 Asia Timur. Indonesia, kata dia, telah mengambil langkah pemberitahuan melalui masing-masing Kedutaan Besar dan telah melakukan pengiriman kembali kontainer-kontainer tersebut ke pelabuhan asal pengiriman.
“Law enforcement juga kami lakukan bagi pihak yang terlibat di dalam negeri. Indonesia mengharapkan kerja sama dengan negara di dunia, termasuk negara di kawasan Asia Timur. Untuk pencegahan pengiriman ilegal limbah B3 sesuai dengan kesepakatan internasional,” ucap Presiden.
Selain limbah B3, kawasan Asia Timur juga menghadapi tantangan sampah plastik laut. Presiden mengingatkan bahwa jika tidak diatasi segera maka ekosistem laut di kawasan Indo-Pasifik akan rusak. “Tahun lalu, kita sepakat menanggulangi sampah plastik laut termasuk mendorong negara Asia Timur untuk memiliki rencana aksi nasional memerangi sampah plastik laut,” kata Jokowi.
Indonesia saat ini sedang menjalankan strategi nasional untuk menangani sampah laut, dari hulu ke hilir. “Saya optimistis Indonesia bisa mencapai target pengurangan sampah laut hingga 70 persen di tahun 2025," ujarnya. Ia berpandangan negara-negara Asia Tenggara harus dapat mendorong gerakan global anti sampah plastik.
Dalam pandangan Presiden Jokowi, gerakan global ini melibatkan sektor swasta aktivis lingkungan, generasi pemuda dan milenial. “Saya berharap negara di kawasan Asia Timur tetap konsisten dalam memerangi sampah plastik dan limbah berbahaya,” ucapnya.
Sementara itu, Menteri Luar Negeri Retno Marsudi yang turut hadir pada KTT tersebut menyampaikan bahwa berdasarkan data bea cukai Indonesia, jumlah kontainer yang diterima di Indonesia hingga saat ini sebanyak 2.194 kontainer hingga Oktober 2019.
“Pihak Bea Cukai dan Kementerian Lingkungan Hidup dan Kehutanan sudah melakukan pemeriksaan terhadap 882 kontainer, dan 374 kontainer sudah dikembalikan ke negara asalnya,” ucap Retno.

Jokowi: Indonesia Rejects Waste Waste from Abroad
Nov 04 2019, 16:51 by Bisnis.com, Rr. Ariyani Yakti Widyastuti
TEMPO.CO, Jakarta - President Joko Widodo or Jokowi stressed that Indonesia refused to become a landfill from abroad. "Surely we all do not want the Southeast Asian region to become a place for disposing of hazardous and toxic waste," President Joko Widodo said, quoted from his official statement, when attending the 14th East Asia Summit in Bangkok, Monday, November 4, 2019.
In recent times, a number of ASEAN countries have received hazardous and toxic material waste from several countries including in the East Asia region. The disposal of hazardous materials, according to Jokowi, violates international rules regarding plastic waste and hazardous toxic waste.
Related to that, Jokowi proposed a cooperation to handle B3 waste and plastic waste at the 14th East Asia Summit. Indonesia, he said, had taken the step of notification through each embassy and had resubmitted the containers to the port of origin of the shipment.
"We also do law enforcement for those involved in the country. Indonesia expects cooperation with countries in the world, including countries in the East Asian region. To prevent illegal shipment of B3 waste in accordance with international agreements, "said the President.
In addition to B3 waste, the East Asian region also faces the challenge of marine plastic waste. The President warned that if it is not resolved immediately the marine ecosystems in the Indo-Pacific region will be damaged. "Last year, we agreed to tackle marine plastic waste, including encouraging East Asian countries to have a national action plan to fight marine plastic waste," Jokowi said.
Indonesia is currently carrying out a national strategy to deal with marine waste, from upstream to downstream. "I am optimistic that Indonesia can achieve the target of reducing marine waste by 70 percent by 2025," he said. He believes Southeast Asian countries must be able to push the global movement against plastic waste.
In the view of President Jokowi, this global movement involves the private sector, environmental activists, youth and millennial generation. "I hope that countries in the East Asia region remain consistent in combating plastic waste and hazardous waste," he said.
Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Retno Marsudi who was also present at the summit said that based on Indonesian customs data, the number of containers received in Indonesia to date was 2,194 containers as of October 2019.
"The Customs and the Ministry of Environment and Forestry has inspected 882 containers, and 374 containers have been returned to their home country," said Retno.
